_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

DOT Foods, Inc. founded in 1960, is the largest food redistributor in the United States serving distributors coast to coast on a daily basis. Headquartered in Mt. Sterling, Illinois, DOT Foods, Inc. is a family owned business that has grown from a single station wagon driven by the founder, Robert Tracy, to a fleet of over 400 multi-temp tractor trailers. This growth is in large part due to the customer driven attitude that is exhibited by all the members of the Dot team.  As stated on their website, "DOT Foods will continue to be driven by the values of integrity, growth, profit, and customer satisfaction, with emphasis on innovation and employee welfare."

DOT Foods, Inc. located in Vidalia, Georgia, provides refrigeration for warehousing and distribution of food and related products and services.  DOT Foods, Inc.?s senior management is not only committed to offering superior service, but also maintains a safety and environmental program to promote a safe environment for all its employees and the surrounding communities.  DOT Foods, Inc. administers safety and environmental policies at the facility to ensure compliance with OSHA?s Process Safety Management (PSM) and EPA?s Risk Management Program (RMP).  These programs include forklift safety, hazard communications, lockout/tagout, employee safety manuals, manufacturers? documentation, and the Emergency Response Plan.

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

DOT Foods, Inc. is located at 1120 W. North St. in Vidalia, Georgia.  The facility is approximately 10 feet north of Highway 292 and 223 feet (0.04 miles) north of the Seaboard Coastline Railroad.  The area surrounding the facility is rural with a mixture of light business and residential areas.

The DOT Foods, Inc. ammonia refrigeration system was built in 1990.  The ammonia refrigeration process was designed and constructed in accordance with all applicable federal, state, and local regulations

.  

The ammonia refrigeration system uses 16,000 pounds of ammonia for dock operations, cold storage, and freezer storage.  The majority of the system is located in the machine room including vessels and compressors.  The condensers and the Thermosyphon Receiver are mounted on the roof above the machine room.  Evaporators are located in their respective cold storage rooms/areas.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The DOT Foods, Inc. facility was designed and constructed in accordance with the Uniform Mechanical Code which specifically outlines requirements for the safe operation of ammonia refrigeration system.  These safety features include ammonia sensors in the machine room as well as sensors in selected cold storage areas, and automatic shut down systems.  In addition, the majority of the ammonia is maintained inside the machine room or outside on the roof above the machine room (condensers and Thermosyphon Receiver).

There are ammonia and temperature sensors placed in the freezer, cooler, and dock areas.  In the event of ammonia detection, a facility alarm sounds and a visible alarm is triggered.  Ammonia sensors are located throughout the facility in the Machine Room, Dock Area, Cooler Areas, and Freezer Area.  These sensors are tied to a central computer that alarms and calls an outside alarm company.  The alarm will activate at one set concentration level.

In addition to the Uniform Mechanical Code, the facility will operate in accordance with the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR) guidelines.  In particular, the IIAR Bulletin 110, "Startup, Inspection, and Maintenance of Ammonia Refrigeration Systems."

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

An investigation into the DOT Foods, Inc. - Vidalia facility?s accident history revealed that there have been no reportable ammonia releases (> 100 pounds) over the past five years (March 2004 ? March 2009).  In addition, there have been no injuries resulting from

an ammonia release.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

DOT Foods, Inc. has an emergency response plan in effect at the facility.  The Emergency Response Plan (Plan) is detailed in the Emergency Planning and Response section of the PSM document, which is maintained at the facility.  This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives:

?     To save lives.
?     To minimize and avoid injuries.
?     To protect the environment.
?     To minimize property damage.

The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  The facility maintains a safety committee (a trained Emergency Response team) whose members are designated emergency coordinators for the facility who will respond to minor leaks.  The emergency response team is trained to call 9-1-1 in an event of an ammonia release.  The 9-1-1 operator will contact the Vidalia Fire Department.  Ammonia sensors are present in the machine room, in selected cold storage areas, and automatic shut down systems.  

Employees within the building are evacuated to a point upwind of the facility or shelter in place.  Evacuation drills are performed annually.  This Plan will be reviewed and updated at least once per year to ensure compliance with the PSM and RMP regulations, as well as to incorporate facility changes due to the renovation of the facility.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) performed on September 9, 2004, generated mitigation measures (recommendations) to improve safety at the DOT Foods, Inc. facility located at 1120 W. North St. in Vidalia, Georgia.  The scheduled completion date of all changes resulting from the PHA update is December 31, 2009.  In the meantime, DOT Foods, Inc.?s safety committee is has completed several items, including the recommendations, in a continual effort to provide

a safe work environment for their employees.  These changes include the following items:

1. Continue to train all employees in Process Safety Management and the facility's Safety Plan/Programs.

2. Continue to have employee involvement in Safety Plan Development.

3. Continue employee involvement through safety team participation.

4. Continue internal and external safety audits/inspections and implement changes as needed.
